page.title: 19THE AREA-Steep to Hawkley 1
page.content: The region north of the Stoner Hill escarpment consists mainly of rolling corn and oilseed rape fields,criss- crossed by roads, long high bushy hedges, ditches and deep folds in the landscape.There's evidence to suggest says local historian, Bill Whiteman, that the Froxfield Plateau was once the site of a large Romano/British cattle ranch & it may be that the area was popular as a Saxon hunting park. Many of the features in the area -ditches,tracks & Wheatham Hill,a pro- -minent feature found to the E of the escarpment-can be easily identified in the Saxon Land Charters &,to this day, form many of the parish boundaries in the area.The escarpment,which bounds the plateau on the eastern & southern edge & which embraces the hangers, was the result,millions of years ago, of dramatic geological activity in Europe
